Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; crudely marked back, with single (very eroded) lines for clypeus, prothorax and elytra; at side, legs only indicated by horizontal line; underside divided into three registers: upper register occupied by a winged sun-disc and double-lines, middle register bearing debased hieroglyphic inscription (vulture with sun-disc on its back and clump of papyrus), and lower register with neb-basket sign; pierced longitudinally; in soft bright blue paste.
Curator's comments: This scarab belongs to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (drawing published in Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 19; on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). It belongs to a type widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Italy and Punic sites and in Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 109-111, type XXX B, subtype B1-10, see especially B10 for this specimen). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 110-111, Type XXX B10)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.52) (phase 3)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Committee of)
